<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (4,4′-bipy=4,4′-bipyridine) (1). Crystal data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>S, tetragonal <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>4<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>acd</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=14.0686(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=14.0686(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=38.759(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=32. elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A simultaneous reduction of SO4 2- to S2- by 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylate under hydrothermal conditions produced a new binuclear copper(II) coordination polymer [CuS(4,4'-bipy)] n  (4,4'-bipy=4,4'-bipyridine) (1). Single crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 consisted of sulfur-bridged binuclear copper(II) units with Cu-Cu bonding which were combined with 4,4'-bipy to generate a three-dimensional network constructed from mutual interpenetration of two-dimensional (6,3) nets. Crystal data for 1: C10H8CuN2S, tetragonal I41/acd, a=14.0686(5)Å, b=14.0686(5)Å, c=38.759(2)Å, Z=32. Other characterizations by elemental analysis, IR, EPR and TGA analysis were also described in this paper.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The design and synthesis of new coordination polymers have attracted great attention in recent years due to their intriguing structural features and potential applications in catalysis, ion-exchange, non-linear optics, chemical adsorption and magnetism . Particular interest has been directed towards binuclear copper coordination polymers because they play an important role in biological metalloenzymes, industrial catalysis  and especially magneto-structural correlations . However, the great majority of these studies are mainly concentrated on carboxylate or halogen-bridged copper(II) complexes , and a minority on sulfur-bridged species because the latter are relatively rare. On the other hand, sulfur-bridged copper(II) coordination polymers are attracting a great deal of attention owing to their relevance to biological, rich structural chemistry, non-linear optic and special reactive properties . Therefore, it would be of interest to synthesize and study the magnetic properties copper(II)-sulfur coordination polymers. To date, sulfur-bridged copper coordination polymers are synthesized usually by conventional solution methodology, while hydrothermal technique is less exploited. Many fascinating structures and unexpected reactions can be achieved under hydrothermal conditions . Although, in most cases, the reaction mechanisms under hydrothermal conditions are not clear and the control and prediction of crystal structures are difficult, the architecture of the final product directly depends on the interplay of the characteristics of metal ion, ligand and reaction conditions . It is well accepted that pyridine derivatives can act as good reductants under hydrothermal conditions , whereas a simultaneous reduction of SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> to S<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> by pyridine derivatives during a self-assembly process has never been observed. In this paper, we report synthesis and crystal structure of a novel coordination polymer: [CuS(4,4′-bipy)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (1). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a three-dimensional network constructed from mutual interpenetration of two-dimensional (6,3) nets, in which sulfur-bridged binuclear copper(II) units are combined with 4,4′-bipy to form sheets of [CuS(4,4′-bipy)]-containing cavities with dimensions of ca. 28×20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of new coordination polymers have attracted great attention in recent years due to their intriguing structural features and potential applications in catalysis, ion-exchange, non-linear optics, chemical adsorption and magnetism . Particular interest has been directed towards binuclear copper coordination polymers because they play an important role in biological metalloenzymes, industrial catalysis  and especially magneto-structural correlations . However, the great majority of these studies are mainly concentrated on carboxylate or halogen-bridged copper(II) complexes , and a minority on sulfur-bridged species because the latter are relatively rare. On the other hand, sulfur-bridged copper(II) coordination polymers are attracting a great deal of attention owing to their relevance to biological, rich structural chemistry, non-linear optic and special reactive properties . Therefore, it would be of interest to synthesize and study the magnetic properties copper(II)-sulfur coordination polymers. To date, sulfur-bridged copper coordination polymers are synthesized usually by conventional solution methodology, while hydrothermal technique is less exploited. Many fascinating structures and unexpected reactions can be achieved under hydrothermal conditions . Although, in most cases, the reaction mechanisms under hydrothermal conditions are not clear and the control and prediction of crystal structures are difficult, the architecture of the final product directly depends on the interplay of the characteristics of metal ion, ligand and reaction conditions . It is well accepted that pyridine derivatives can act as good reductants under hydrothermal conditions , whereas a simultaneous reduction of SO4 2- to S2- by pyridine derivatives during a self-assembly process has never been observed. In this paper, we report synthesis and crystal structure of a novel coordination polymer: [CuS(4,4'-bipy)] n  (1). Compound 1 exhibits a three-dimensional network constructed from mutual interpenetration of two-dimensional (6,3) nets, in which sulfur-bridged binuclear copper(II) units are combined with 4,4'-bipy to form sheets of [CuS(4,4'-bipy)]-containing cavities with dimensions of ca. 28×20Å.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General procedures

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental Analyzer. IR spectrum was obtained on Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrometer with KBr pellet in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. The EPR spectrum was recorded on a Japanese JES-FE3AX spectrometer at room temperature. The TG analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

The title compound was hydrothermally synthesized from the reaction mixture of CuSO4⋅5H2O (0.5 mmol), 4,4'-bipy (0.5 mmol), 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (0.5 mmol), NaOH (1 mmol) and H2O (8 ml) at 190 °C for 3 days, followed by slowly cooling (5 °C/h) to room temperature. Dark red block crystals of 1 were recovered in 30% yield based on 4,4'-bipy. C10H8CuN2S (251.8): Calcd C, 47.66; H, 3.18; N, 11.12 (%). Found C, 47.58; H, 3.24; N, 11.04 (%).

elements.content: X-ray crystallographyThe crystal structure of compound 1 was determined by single-crystal X-Ray diffraction. Crystal data: C10H8CuN2S, tetragonal I41/acd, a=14.0686(5)Å, b=14.0686(5)Å, c=38.759(2)Å, Z=32. The crystal determination for compound 1 was performed on a Bruker Smart-CCD diffractometer with MoKα Monochromated radiation (λ=0.71073 A ̊ ) at 293 K in the range of 2.07°<θ<27.45°. The structure was solved by direct methods using the program SHELXL-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the SHELXL crystallographic software package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps. The crystal data and structure refinement, atomic coordinates, and selected bond lengths and angles of compound 1 were listed in .

The Cu(II) center is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different 4,4′-bipy groups and two sulfur bridged-ligands to form binuclear copper(II) units with Cu–Cu distance of 2.759<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The Cu–N bond lengths vary from 1.982(3) to 1.985(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cu–S bond lengths range from 2.4212(14) to 2.4524(14)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The N(S)–Cu–S(N) bond angles range from 99.69(12) to 127.43(14)°. Thus, all Cu centers display distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Each 4,4′-bipy adopts a bismonodentate bridging mode to link two sulfur-bridged binuclear copper(II) units (Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). It should be noted that the two pyridine rings in the two independent 4,4′-bipy are twisted by 22.7(6) and 16.5(4)°, respectively. Based on this connection mode, all Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units are combined by 4,4′-bipy to form hexagonal rings (size ca. 28×20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), which form a two-dimensional (6,3) net (see )<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure

The X-ray single-crystal analysis reveals that compound 1 is a three-dimensional network constructed from mutual interpenetration of two-dimensional (6,3) nets. The fundamental unit is shown in  . There is only one crystallographically unique Cu(II) center in the crystal structure. The Cu(II) center is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different 4,4'-bipy groups and two sulfur bridged-ligands to form binuclear copper(II) units with Cu-Cu distance of 2.759Å. The Cu-N bond lengths vary from 1.982(3) to 1.985(3)Å, and the Cu-S bond lengths range from 2.4212(14) to 2.4524(14)Å. The N(S)-Cu-S(N) bond angles range from 99.69(12) to 127.43(14)°. Thus, all Cu centers display distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Each 4,4'-bipy adopts a bismonodentate bridging mode to link two sulfur-bridged binuclear copper(II) units (Cu2S2). It should be noted that the two pyridine rings in the two independent 4,4'-bipy are twisted by 22.7(6) and 16.5(4)°, respectively. Based on this connection mode, all Cu2S2 units are combined by 4,4'-bipy to form hexagonal rings (size ca. 28×20Å), which form a two-dimensional (6,3) net (see ).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In the packing arrangement of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, there are four crystallographically identical yet topologically independent (6,3) nets that can be grouped into two sets, one with two vertical and parallel nets and the other with two horizontal and parallel nets. These networks interpenetrate with mutual interlocking of the hexagons to result in a three-dimensional framework (see )<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. However, there does not exist bond interaction among the interlocking two-dimensional (6,3) nets. Interpenetration in nature is a space-filling effect to produce dense framework, but, surprisingly, the interpenetrating two-dimensional networks do not fill up all the pore space formed by one independent two-dimensional network. A perspective view of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> clearly shows there are one-dimensional channels (size ca. 2×4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis (see )<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>

These networks interpenetrate with mutual interlocking of the hexagons to result in a three-dimensional framework (see ). However, there does not exist bond interaction among the interlocking two-dimensional (6,3) nets. Interpenetration in nature is a space-filling effect to produce dense framework, but, surprisingly, the interpenetrating two-dimensional networks do not fill up all the pore space formed by one independent two-dimensional network. A perspective view of compound 1 clearly shows there are one-dimensional channels (size ca. 2×4Å) along the c axis (see ).

elements.content:
It is interesting to note that SO4 2− ions were reduced to S2− by 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylate under hydrothermal conditions, at the same time, 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylate transforms into pyridine. To the best of our knowledge, this reduction reaction in constructing coordination polymers is unique. To verify this deduction, we repeated the reaction without adding 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid and did not obtain compound 1. SO 4 2−+C 5 H 3 N(COO)2 2− → 190°C
    Cu 2++4,4′-bipy
S 2−+C 5 H 5 N+CO 2

elements.clean_text:
IR spectrum

In the infrared spectrum of compound 1, absorption bands from 1608.5 to 1411.7 cm-1 are attributed to the pyridine ring breathing bands of 4,4'-bipy.

EPR spectrum

The EPR spectrum of compound 1 exhibits the Cu2+ signal at 293 K with g=2.0332, which is consistent with the result of valence sum calculations.

Thermal analysis

Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out under N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The TG curve of compound 1 (shown in ) indicates three steps of weight loss. The first two stages of weight loss are 61.89% (calcd: 62.15%) in the temperature range 190-320 °C, corresponding to the release of the 4,4'-bipy ligands. The third weight loss occurs from 320 to 520 °C, due to the release of part of sulfur. After decomposition of compound 1 at high temperature, the weight of the residue (~31.29%) is responded to Cu2S (calcd: 31.90%).

<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ions are reduced to S<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ions by 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylate under hydrothermal conditions. This provides a possible method to in situ generate sulfur-contained coordination polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized a novel coordination polymer consisting of two-dimensional (6,3) nets under hydrothermal conditions. The result reveals that SO4 2- ions are reduced to S2- ions by 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylate under hydrothermal conditions. This provides a possible method to in situ generate sulfur-contained coordination polymers.

X-ray crystallography

The crystal structure of compound 1 was determined by single-crystal X-Ray diffraction. Crystal data: C10H8CuN2S, tetragonal I41/acd, a=14.0686(5)Å, b=14.0686(5)Å, c=38.759(2)Å, Z=32. The crystal determination for compound 1 was performed on a Bruker Smart-CCD diffractometer with MoKα Monochromated radiation (λ=0.71073   A  ̊  ) at 293 K in the range of 2.07°<θ<27.45°. The structure was solved by direct methods using the program SHELXL-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the SHELXL crystallographic software package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps. The crystal data and structure refinement, atomic coordinates, and selected bond lengths and angles of compound 1 were listed in    .

IR spectrum

In the infrared spectrum of compound 1, absorption bands from 1608.5 to 1411.7 cm-1 are attributed to the pyridine ring breathing bands of 4,4'-bipy.

EPR spectrum

The EPR spectrum of compound 1 exhibits the Cu2+ signal at 293 K with g=2.0332, which is consistent with the result of valence sum calculations.

Thermal analysis

Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out under N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The TG curve of compound 1 (shown in ) indicates three steps of weight loss. The first two stages of weight loss are 61.89% (calcd: 62.15%) in the temperature range 190-320 °C, corresponding to the release of the 4,4'-bipy ligands. The third weight loss occurs from 320 to 520 °C, due to the release of part of sulfur. After decomposition of compound 1 at high temperature, the weight of the residue (~31.29%) is responded to Cu2S (calcd: 31.90%).
